title: Darts news: Rob Cross takes aim at Michael van Gerwen after European Championship win
text:
Rob Cross claimed his third major title at the European Championship (Picture: Kais Bodensieck/PDC Europe)

Rob Cross has his sights firmly set on knocking Michael van Gerwen off his perch as world number one after his European Championship victory at the weekend.

The world number two won his third PDC major title on Sunday as he beat Gerwyn Price in the final in Gottingen, picking up £120,000 for his troubles.

The victory for Voltage saw him make ground on Van Gerwen at the top of the world rankings after MVG crashed out in round one against Ross Smith, and saw his £100,000 prize money for winning the event in 2017 fall off the rankings.

Having also picked up the World Matchplay title, and the £150,000 that comes with it, Cross is making serious strides and firmly believes he will claim the number one spot at some point.

‘I’m here to be number one in the world,’ said Cross after beating Price. ‘I don’t play to make up the numbers and I believe I will be number one at some point.

‘I’m playing great, I’m having to dig deep at times and I’m more feeling like myself. It’s amazing and it’s everything I wanted it to be.’

Van Gerwen fell at the first hurdle at the European Championship (Picture: Kais Bodensieck/PDC Europe)

While Cross admitted that Van Gerwen’s early exit in Germany was helpful to his cause, he remained certain that he will dethrone the Dutchman at some stage.

‘I always want number one,’ continued Cross to Live Darts. ‘I wouldn’t be here making the numbers up and letting him have it his own way.

‘He is the best player in the world at the minute, I know he crashed out and gave me an easier draw, that’s no disrespect to anyone else.

‘I think, realistically, I want to be number one, it doesn’t matter if I become number one in three months time or in a year’s time.

‘We all have our aims and I will be number one.’

Cross still has a long way to go to catch Van Gerwen at the top of the rankings, as following the European Championship MVG is on £1,560,750 with Cross at £998,750.

There is also serious pressure on Voltage at the World Championship, starting on 13 December, as he is defending the £400,000 he picked up for winning the tournament in 2018.

The only way Cross can increase the money on his ranking is by lifting the trophy again at the Alexandra Palace, pocketing £500,000 for his work over the festive period.

Cross and Van Gerwen are back in action this weekend at the non-ranking World Series of Darts finals in Amsterdam.
